title: How to Clean Shower Tile

steps.headline: Run your shower on a high temperature.
steps.description: Let the hot water run for at least 10 minutes. The hot water will open the tile’s pores, making it easier to clean.

steps.headline: Mix 1 part vinegar to 1 part water in a bowl.
steps.description: Mix the ingredients together in the bowl until they are well-combined. Then fill a spray bottle with the solution. These types of cleaners are safe for everyday use and won't cause skin irritation.

steps.headline: Spray the solution onto your shower tiles.
steps.description: Make sure to spray more solution onto dirtier areas, as well as the spaces in between the tiles, i.e., the grout. Since you will be using this solution later on, do not use up all of the solution at this point, or make more solution as you clean.

steps.headline: Let the solution set for five minutes.
steps.description: This will loosen the soap scum. Depending on how dirty your tiles are, you may need to let the solution set for 30 minutes or longer.

steps.headline: Scrub the soap scum.
steps.description: Use a stiff bristle brush or a grout brush to do this. This will further loosen the soap scum, making the tiles easier to clean.

steps.headline: Rinse with warm water.
steps.description: Do this by turning your shower on again. Use a lower temperature setting. However, the water should still be warm. Alternatively, you can use a bucket or a pitcher to rinse the tiles.

parts.name: Cleaning the Tiles with a Baking Soda Paste

steps.headline: Mix 3 parts baking soda to 1 part water in a bowl.
steps.description: Mix the baking soda and water together until it forms a thick paste. The paste should have a toothpaste-like consistency. If the mixture is thin, then keep adding more baking soda until it reaches the desired thickness. For tough stains, add hydrogen peroxide to the mix by substituting half of the water with peroxide. Alternatively, you can use a tile cleaner to clean your tiles if you do not want to use a baking soda paste.

steps.headline: Apply the paste with a sponge.
steps.description: Do this by spreading the paste over the tiles. Make sure to apply a generous amount in between the tiles and on tough stains.

steps.headline: Spray the paste with the vinegar solution.
steps.description: The vinegar will react with the baking soda, making it bubble. The vinegar helps the paste eat through the soap scum.

steps.headline: Scrub your tiles with a scrub brush.
steps.description: Use a stiff bristle brush or a grout brush. Scrub your tiles in a circular motion. Use pressure to remove tough stains and mildew from the tile, as well as when cleaning in between the tiles. For small crevices, use a toothbrush.

steps.headline: Rinse with warm water.
steps.description: Use a bucket or pitcher to rinse your tiles. Pour the water over the tiles until all the soap and residue are removed. You may need to rinse your tiles three to five times.

steps.headline: Dry the tiles with a clean towel.
steps.description: This will prevent water from pooling in corners and crevices, which will help in the prevention of mold and mildew growth.

steps.headline: Spray the vinegar solution onto the tiles.
steps.description: Do this after you finish showering two to three times a week. This will help keep your shower tiles clean for a longer period of time. Keep a spray bottle labeled “shower spray” in your shower for easy access. If you have children, keep the bottle up high and out of reach.

steps.headline: Squeegee your tiles.
steps.description: Do this by keeping a squeegee in your bathroom. Squeegee your bathroom tiles five to seven times a week after showering. Make sure to squeegee corners and crevices.

steps.headline: Dry your tiles with a towel.
steps.description: Keep a specially designated towel handy in your bathroom to do this. Dry your tiles off five to seven times a week after showering.
